Class OrderedList<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T> & Copyable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • OrderedList<T>
  • public class OrderedList<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T> & Copyable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
    A list of generic type maintained in order. Order is determined by the user providing a Comparator or if none provided, using the compareTo method of type T. This is a DYNAMICALLY SIZED list, meaning that it has no capacity limit. Any type used with this class must implement both Comparable (a Java interface) and Copyable (a made-up interface for this assignment).

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      OrderedList()
      Default constructor, which does not have Comparator defined, thus order should be based on compareTo method of T.
      OrderedList​(java.util.Comparator<T> order)
      Constructor with Comparator, which is used for maintaining list order.

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • add

        public void add​(T object)
        Add element to list such that the ordering is maintained. IMPLEMENTATION: Iterate from the last element to the first, shifting as you go to create the most efficient add method. Use the Comparator to determine placement in order. If the list is full, then increase the capacity by the specified default for increasing size.
        Parameters:
        object - to be added

      • toArray

        public T[] toArray()
        A copy of the list in which each element is a new object with copied content (using Copyable), maintaining its order, and placing into a new array. IMPLEMENTATION: Use the copyThis method in the Copyable interface to create a true copy of the list element.
        Returns:
        array the size of the number of elements in the list.

      • toArray

        public T[] toArray​(java.util.Comparator<T> sortBy)
        A copy of the list in which each element is a new object with copied content (using Copyable), but in the order of "sortBy" NOT the class Comparator.
        Parameters:
        sortBy - Comparator establishing order of returned array.
        Returns:
        array the size of the number of elements in the list.

      • reorder

        public void reorder​(java.util.Comparator<T> order)
        The list should now be maintained according to the provided comparator. It must be reordered. IMPLEMENTATION: Use your private sort method to reorder the elements according to the parameter Comparator. Don't forget to set your class Comparator to this new value.
        Parameters:
        order - establishes ordering of list elements.

      • find

        public int find​(T item)
        Determine location within the list of given item. The first element is at location 0. peek(find(X)) should return X. IMPLEMENTATION: Use BINARY SEARCH to find an element. Use the class Comparator within the method. This can be iterative or recursive.
        Parameters:
        item - Object to locate in list.
        Returns:
        location of the object or -1 if not in the list.

      • findAll

        public java.util.ArrayList<T> findAll​(java.lang.Object key,
                                      java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> comp)
        Find all elements that match the key value (using the Comparator input parameter, and return copies in an ArrayList. IMPLEMENTATION: Copy these elements using copyThis, and place these copied elements in a new ArrayList (Yes, that is Java's ArrayList!). Note that if the list is empty, return an empty ArrayList (not null).
        Parameters:
        key - Value of field to match.
        comp - used to find matches between key and list items.
        Returns:
        ArrayList of all items that match key. EMPTY if none (not null!)

      • findAllOr

        public java.util.ArrayList<T> findAllOr​(java.lang.Object key1,
                                        java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> comp1,
                                        java.lang.Object key2,
                                        java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> comp2)
        Find all elements that match either key1 OR key2 value using the input parameter Comparators, and return copies in an ArrayList. IMPLEMENTATION: Copy these elements using copyThis, and place these copied elements in a new ArrayList (Yes, that is Java's ArrayList!). Note that if the list is empty, return an empty ArrayList (not null).
        Parameters:
        key1 - 1 of 2 values of field that potentially match.
        comp1 - used to find matches to key1
        key2 - 1 of 2 values of field that potentially match.
        comp2 - used to find matches to key2
        Returns:
        ArrayList of all items that match either key. EMPTY if none (not null!)

      • findInRangeInclusive

        public java.util.ArrayList<T> findInRangeInclusive​(java.lang.Object keyMin,
                                                   java.lang.Object keyMax,
                                                   java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> comp)
        Find all elements whose key field value is between keyMin and keyMax using the input parameter Comparator, and return copies in an ArrayList. IMPLEMENTATION: Copy these elements using copyThis, and place these copied elements in a new ArrayList (Yes, that is Java's ArrayList!). Note that if the list is empty, return an empty ArrayList (not null).
        Parameters:
        keyMin - smallest value that key could match
        keyMax - largest value that key could match
        comp - used to establish order between keyMin and keyMax
        Returns:
        ArrayList of all items with values in range. EMPTY if none (not null!)

      • retainInRangeInclusive

        public void retainInRangeInclusive​(java.lang.Object keyMin,
                                   java.lang.Object keyMax,
                                   java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> comp)
        Keep only those list elements whose key field value is between keyMin and keyMax using the input parameter Comparator. All other elements should be removed from the list.
        Parameters:
        keyMin - smallest value that key could match
        keyMax - largest value that key could match
        comp - used to establish order between keyMin and keyMax

      • removeInRangeInclusive

        public void removeInRangeInclusive​(java.lang.Object keyMin,
                                   java.lang.Object keyMax,
                                   java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> comp)
        Remove all list elements whose key field value is between keyMin and keyMax using the input parameter Comparator. All other elements should remain in the list.
        Parameters:
        keyMin - smallest value that key could match
        keyMax - largest value that key could match
        comp - used to establish order between keyMin and keyMax

      • max

        public T max()
        Find the maximum value according to the class Comparator. IMPLEMENTATION: No need to iterate!
        Returns:
        Max element in the list or null if list is empty.

        public T min()
        Find the minimum value according to the class Comparator. IMPLEMENTATION: No need to iterate!
        Returns:
        Min element in the list or null if list is empty.
